Award.AwardTitle: High-Order Added-Mass Partitioned Algorithms for Fluid-Structure Interaction Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will dramatically improve computer algorithms used for the simulation of important problems in applied science, engineering, and bio-medicine, such as the modeling of blood flow in human veins, which provides critical data to evaluate surgical procedures and to design medical devices and implants. The area of fluid-structure interaction (i.e. coupling fluids with deforming solids), which this project addresses, is of current and growing interest due to its importance in many areas of engineering and applied science, including not only bio-medicine but also the modeling of flow-induced vibrations of structures (aircraft, undersea cables, wind turbines, buildings), wave energy devices, parachutes and airbags, acoustic lenses, thermal expansion in nuclear reactor cores, and shock-structure interactions (blast effects). Computing accurate solutions of fluid-structure interaction problems efficiently is very challenging due to their complex physical and geometrical properties, but also due to challenging mathematical issues. The new techniques developed by this project will address both these challenges.

A wide class of important fluid-structure interaction (FSI) problems are difficult to simulate due to the so-called added mass instability. The focus of the research is on FSI problems coupling incompressible flow with elastic or rigid structures. Of particular interest are problems in which the mass of the fluid and that of the structure are similar, such as in applications of hemodynamics, where added-mass effects are strong. The overarching goal of this project is to develop stable and high-order accurate partitioned algorithms for FSI problems that overcome the numerical difficulties associated with complex fluid-solid couplings and strong added-mass effects. These algorithms will be based on newly devised Added-Mass Partitioned (AMP) schemes that represent a conceptual breakthrough in the field by providing a path forward to develop accurate schemes for fluid-structure interaction problems. An important property of AMP schemes is that they remain stable even for light solids when added-mass effects are significant. The new algorithms will be incorporated into a flexible computational framework that will allow efficient simulations for wide class of complex fluid-structure interaction problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluid-structure interaction (FSI) problems arise in many areas of engineering and applied science, and the corresponding development, analysis and implementation of numerical methods for these problems is a very active area of research.  Despite the many advances in numerical schemes for FSI simulations, there remains a critical need for improved algorithms, especially for more accurate, flexible and efficient algorithms that can treat large changes in the geometry.  In addition, for problems involving incompressible flows coupled to relatively light structures (e.g. blood flow in deformable arteries), there is a pressing need for algorithms that can overcome the so-called added-mass instability.  Monolithic schemes have been employed to avoid this instability (but can be expensive), whereas current partitioned schemes often require tens or hundreds of expensive sub-time-step iterations; the instability becoming worse for lighter solids or as the grid for the simulation is refined to achieve higher fidelity.

The focus of the work within this project was the development and analysis of new partitioned algorithms for the solution of FSI problems.  The central design goal of these new Added-Mass Partitioned (AMP) algorithms was (1) provable stability, without sub-time-step iterations, for a wide range of solid densities (including very light solids), (2) high-order accuracy, and (3) flexibility to handle complex geometric configurations.  Following these design principles, we developed AMP algorithms for (i) FSI problems coupling incompressible flows with elastic bulk solids or thin structures and (ii) FSI problems coupling incompressible flow with rigid solids.  A key outcome of the project was the development of new AMP Interface conditions that are employed in the AMP algorithms, leading to stable partitioned algorithms, without sub-time-iterations, thus overcoming added-mass instabilities and a more subtle added-damping instability.

In related work, we developed the CHAMP algorithm for the simulation of conjugate heat transfer between materials with different thermal properties. The CHAMP approach provides a new treatment of the interface conditions for the temperature used by partitioned solvers that effectively eliminates expensive sub-iterations of the interface conditions needed by traditional partitioned algorithms.  The key to the CHAMP approach is the incorporation of compatibility interface conditions into the standard jump conditions, and combining these with an optimized Schwartz-type scheme that defines an optimal mixing of the interface conditions involving the temperature and the heat flux.  A final accomplishment of the project was the development of efficient fourth-order accurate fractional-step schemes for simulating incompressible flows, which has important applications to the simulation of turbulent flows. The new schemes are able to locally decouple the solution of the elliptic equation for the pressure in one step from the time-evolution of the velocity in the other step, which is important for efficiency while at the same time retaining the high-order accuracy. To our knowledge, these new fractional-step schemes are the first fourth-order accurate schemes of this type developed.

The intellectual merit of the research accomplished rests on the development and analysis of the new high-order accurate AMP algorithms for FSI problems, with and without conjugate heat transfer, involving incompressible flow coupled to elastic and rigid structures, and on the implementation and application of the new methods for a wide range of FSI problems in two and three dimensions.  The broader impact of the project concerns new theoretical and practical applications of the partitioned algorithms developed, which are more accurate, stable and efficient than the current state-of-the-art partitioned schemes, especially when added-mass effects are significant.  These algorithms are available in open-source software at www.overtureframework.org.  A further outcome and impact of the project has been on the career development of students and postdoctoral researchers who have made important contributions to the work accomplished.  In particular, the contributions of two graduate students formed the content of their Ph.D. dissertations.


Last Modified: 12/12/2019
Modified by: Donald W Schwendeman

Image
  • Fluid-structure interaction of incompressible flow past three deforming bodies computed with the new added-mass partitioned scheme.
    W.D. Henshaw

    William D Henshaw
    FSI
